In ancient Greece, the calendar was based on the cycles of the moon, and years were not numbered in the same way that they are today. Instead, years were named for important events, people, or gods. For example, a year might be named for the festival of Dionysus or for the Olympic Games.

There was no concept of a "year zero," and the years were not numbered consecutively. Instead, the years were counted from the mythical foundation of the city or state. For example, the year 1 in Athens might correspond to the year 753 BCE in the modern calendar, while the year 1 in Corinth might correspond to the year 725 BCE.

Despite this, the ancient Greeks did have a way of counting the years, using a system called the "era of the Olympiads." This system counted the years based on the cycles of the Olympic Games, which were held every four years. The first Olympic Games are traditionally dated to 776 BCE, and the era of the Olympiads began at that time. Under this system, the year 1 of the era of the Olympiads corresponded to the year 776 BCE, and each subsequent year was numbered consecutively.

This system of counting the years was used primarily for dating events and keeping track of historical records, rather than for everyday purposes. It was not until the introduction of the Julian calendar in 45 BCE that a more standardized system of year numbering was adopted in the ancient Greek world.
